thread.title: MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD
thread.title_full: MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD

title: MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD The Michigan State player who recovered the fumble and raced 38-yards for the game-winning TD, with a broken hip, retraces his steps. Post to Facebook MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD The Michigan State player who recovered the fumble and raced 38-yards for the game-winning TD, with a broken hip, retraces his steps.  //detne.ws/1RWtwjL   2   MSU's Jalen Watts-Jackson recounts momentous TD Jalen Watts-Jackson discusses his special teams play that won the game against Michigan, and his subsequent injury. Daniel Mears, The Detroit News Matt Charboneau , The Detroit News 2:09 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 MSU sports information director John Lewandowski wheels Michigan State red-shirt freshman safety Jalen Watts-Jackson, who made the game winning fumble recovery and touchdown over Michigan, and was injured on the play, into a press conference at Spartan Stadium. (Photo: Daniel Mears, Detroit News) 
East Lansing â€“ Jalen Watts-Jackson remembers the play vividly, he also remembers how it felt when he crossed the goal-line. 
"It was pure pain," the redshirt freshman safety said. 
But he'd do it all again to experience what he has since he scored the winning touchdown against Michigan on Saturday. It was the final play and Watts-Jackson carried a fumbled punt 38 yards for the score, giving Michigan State a 27-23 victory. 
He also disclocated his hip in the process. 
"If I had to do it all over again," Watts-Jackson said, "I definitely would." 
In his first chance to talk since returning from the University of Michigan Hospital on Monday, Watts-Jackson thanked the staff at the hospital and his teammates for how they've supported him. 
"They told me, 'Bro, they're gonna put a statue up for you,' " Watts-Jackson joked. 
He said he'll be off the hip for about three months and won't be back to running for six to seven months, but he hopes to defy the odds and get back quicker. MSU hero describes his thoughts in the hospital after he scored the winning touchdown but broke his hip. Daniel Mears, The Detroit News 1 CONNECT 12 TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://detne.ws/1RWtwjL TOP VIDEOS
